abstract: E-mail messages released by the Senate subcommittee on investigations and by Goldman Sachs itself suggest an increasing dependence on written messages.
snippet: E-mail messages released by the Senate subcommittee on investigations and by Goldman Sachs itself suggest an increasing dependence on written messages.
lead_paragraph: Embarrassing e-mail messages aren’t new to Wall Street. After the dot-com bubble popped, star technology analysts were condemned for sending messages mocking the same stocks they had urged investors to buy.

byline.original: By PETER THAL LARSEN and FIONA MAHARG BRAVO
